A coat should ideally have a water-resistant exterior, with a warm and breathable insulation layer within. A coat that is loose and voluminous in the torso will be more comfortable and effective in cold weather than a tightly-fitted or conforming style.  Sleeves should also be sufficiently roomy and flexible in order to accommodate mittens, gloves, or bare hands without constricting movements or becoming snagged on obstructions. Human: I am looking to make a recipe with only the following ingredients: Chicken, black beans, two onions, one green bell pepper, salt, black pepper and a pint of grape tomatoes. I also have about one half of a box of angel hair pasta. Is there recipe I can make out of these ingredients?

Assistant:
chosen:
Sure, here’s a basic recipe that you can use. You should double the recipe if you have a larger group of people since this makes two main dish servings. You will also need some basic kitchen equipment like a large pot, a cutting board, a knife, etc.  

For the pasta:  

Heat about 4 cups of water in a large pot until boiling, then add the box of angel hair pasta.  Cook it according to the package directions, until al dente.  Drain and set aside.  

For the main dish:  

In a large frying pan or saucepan, heat about 1 tablespoon of olive oil over medium heat.  Add the two onions and cook for about 5 minutes, until they are softened.  Add the chicken and cook for about 7 minutes, until it is cooked through.  Add the two bell peppers, black beans, salt, pepper, and one cup of water.  Cover and simmer for about 10 minutes, until the beans are tender.  Add the grape tomatoes and cook for another 5-10 minutes, until the tomatoes have softened.  Finally, add the cooked angel hair pasta and toss to combine.  Serve hot.  

Note:  You can substitute any chicken breasts for the boneless chicken breasts in this recipe, as long as they are around the same size.  You can also vary the amount of onion, bell peppers, and tomatoes to taste.

These all sound pretty good, but the one you described -- spaghetti with chicken and black bean sauce -- sounds like a classic, really tasty dish. Hope that helps!

Neuro-long COVID is a very important problem in the U.S. It affects millions of people and leads to people not being able to work the way they used to, or to lose time from work," Igor Koralnik, chief of neuro-infectious diseases and global neurology at Northwestern Memorial Hospital, tells Axios.

"It's the third-most frequent neurological condition in the U.S. today," says Koralnik, who started a long COVID clinic in May 2020 that's treated about 1,200 patients.


The mystery of how SARS-CoV-2 may cause brain fog or other neurological symptoms in some people is driving new global research.

Why it matters: Roughly 79 million Americans contracted COVID-19 in the first two years of the pandemic. While most survived, many are grappling with long-term symptoms, or long COVID, that affect the brain and other body systems.


"Neuro-long COVID is a very important problem in the U.S. It affects millions of people and leads to people not being able to work the way they used to, or to lose time from work," Igor Koralnik, chief of neuro-infectious diseases and global neurology at Northwestern Memorial Hospital, tells Axios.

There's an "urgent need" to research the disorders and develop therapies, NIH's Avindra Nath and Yale's Serena Spudich wrote in a January Science perspective.

"It's the third-most frequent neurological condition in the U.S. today," says Koralnik, who started a long COVID clinic in May 2020 that's treated about 1,200 patients.

How it works
Some of the big questions researchers are trying to answer: if and how the virus is breaching the protective blood-brain barrier, how it is damaging the brain, and if the effect is permanent.

Most of the accumulated data so far is based on adults, so there's less known about how the virus affects the brains of older teens or children and infants.

Accessing the brain: The blood-brain barrier often prevents many germs from reaching the brain, but certain pathogens are able to breach it.

Whether SARS-CoV-2 has the ability to directly cross that barrier remains in question, although recent studies indicate it can.

Autopsies have also found SARS-CoV-2 infections in cells near the brain can inflame the brain-barrier cells and that this inflammation can be relayed into the brain's neurons and glial cells.

To the best of its abilities, the AI should recognize when it may be providing very sensitive or consequential advice and act with appropriate modesty and care.
